message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the purulent material and submandibular lymphadenopathy, suggest Actinomyces infection, which is commonly treated with doxycycline. Surgical resection may be necessary for advanced or chronic cases, but antibiotics are the first-line treatment. The Gram stain showing gram-positive filamentous rods also supports the diagnosis of Actinomyces. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not effective against Actinomyces.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and Gram stain results suggest the diagnosis of actinomycosis. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be necessary in cases of extensive tissue destruction. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not effective against actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of gram-positive filamentous rods suggest actinomycosis. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, doxycycline is the preferred therapy for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be necessary in advanced cases but should not be the first step. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and cephalexin are not effective against actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests Actinomyces infection, which is commonly associated with dental procedures. The next best step in management is treatment with antibiotics, and the best choice is doxycycline. Surgical resection may be necessary for complicated cases, but antibiotics should be started first to decrease the size of the abscess. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not effective against Actinomyces.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms point to actinomycosis, an infection caused by the gram-positive filamentous rods seen on Gram stain. Doxycycline is an appropriate treatment for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be necessary in some cases, but antibiotic therapy is often the first-line treatment. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not typically used to treat actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a chronic infection and gram-positive filamentous rods, suggesting actinomycosis. Doxycycline is the preferred antibiotic for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be required if there is abscess formation or to debulk the mass, but antibiotic treatment is the first-line therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and cephalexin are not effective against actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest actinomycosis, which is caused by gram-positive filamentous rods. Treatment with doxycycline or penicillin is recommended. Surgical resection may be necessary if antibiotics are unsuccessful. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not effective against Actinomyces.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of purulent material and gram-positive filamentous rods suggests a bacterial infection, most likely actinomycosis. Doxycycline is an appropriate treatment for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be necessary if there is no response to antibiotic therapy. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin are not effective treatments for actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and gram-positive filamentous rods indicate actinomycosis, a bacterial infection often associated with dental extractions. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for actinomycosis. Surgical resection may be necessary in severe cases, but antibiotics should be started first. The other options are not appropriate for treating actinomycosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the Gram stain suggest Actinomyces infection. Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for Actinomyces infections. Surgical resection may not be necessary if the infection can be treated effectively with antibiotics. Trimethoprim-sulfamethaxazole and cephalexin may not be effective against Actinomyces.
